message: This can change the game in a lot of aspects. What happen if the startup does not have enough traction the first years?
I would imagine deport after 2 years.
Just hope that it gets passed soon!

I believe it might be good pass for already existing, young local startups to get or build attention overseas and go closer to Silicon Valley. Unity (www.unity3d.com) is good example of succeeded company making exactly those moves. They started in Denmark but quickly moved to US and with SV investment they have succeeded globally.
@glorithm deportation sounds harsh..maybe downgrade to an F1 (in the case of students) or H1B in the case of able workers would be better?
I hope someone gives these founders a heads up about "The Heart Taxation Act" and what happens when they stay for 8 years. My wife an i will be leaving the USA before Dec 2015 for this very reason.

@gduplessy from the original TC article - "Yes, there is a risk for holders of this visa that, if their venture fails or doesn’t go anywhere, they must start again or leave the U.S. But that’s entrepreneurship—there are no guarantees. This won’t appeal to everyone, and it is not meant to. The Startup Visa is for risk takers."
Start over again is one thing, but with the original requirements, it could be too much risks.  Hopefully the new version will pass soon, for myself and for others.
Some pretty big numbers on the sheet for that Visa; I'd imagine that, if it failed, the E1 Treaty Trader visa could also be a potential fallback, too.
@glorithm sounds fair when viewed like that

I think it is a very fair bill, lets hope they don't screw it up. The numbers are fine too now, especially when compared to E2, where the money has to come from the outside of the US (and has some more strings attached).
